author: perama
content:
Consider a period where the basefee has risen very high (from 200% full blocks for a prolonged period from some special event) to the point where all users are unwilling to pay

If a single user is willing to pay for a transaction at that extreme price, the block would be 99% empty. The basefee couldn't fall, so that person could keep sending single transactions that pin the basefee to that high level.

Perhaps this is a relatively low cost way to halt useful activity for a moderate amount of time?

author: perama
content: As in every miner knows that many empty blocks need to be mined to get down to the meaty transaction fees, but doesn't want to be the miner to do it. Instead choosing to include the single transaction, whether by "choice" for slightly more immediate profit, or by a default in the mining software.

author: timbeiko
content: That‚Äôs not true: if there is a single txn (assuming it doesn‚Äôt consume all gas), the base fee will lower. It goes from -12.5% to +12.5% linearly between 0 and 200% of gas used

author: sky.cactus
content: It can never rise to a point where *all* users are unwilling to pay.  Though, it can raise to a point where all the users that are willing to pay are no *longer* willing to pay, which I think is what you are getting at.

author: sky.cactus
content: Tim's answer though is correct, it would just decrease the block limit by 12.49% instead of 12.5% or something.

author: perama
content: Perfect, the linear mechanism is what I had overlooked. TYVM

author: Deleted User
content: The reason is to make the market more efficient, the current auction is not using all the information available. The sender is happy to pay any value between BASE_FEE and BASE_FEE+PREMIUM but its always paying BASE_FEE+PREMIUM. Also when the MEV arbitrage transactions come, they buy the whole block with an exorbitant price and left the regular sender with signal that is not very robust for external estimators and wallets. [EIP-3416](https://github.com/ethereum/EIPs/blob/master/EIPS/eip-3416.md)

author: Deleted User
content: thanks for your response, our pitch is that 3416 could give the same or more benefits as 1559 but with a *smaller implementation footprint*. Vis-a-vis, miner pricing changes but no changes to Tx Format and no changes to wallets. But we completely understand that 1559 could be in implementation phase so rolling-back that will be costly. Also, some parts have not been analysed in-length enough (the weighted median possibly, there are some simulations with main-net data but without base fees ). Although the additive changes in baseFee, I saw that is has a lot of positive feedback in the forum, and possibly has more chances to get into "1559 v2". My main concern is what is the cost of upgrading all wallets, gas station estimators and light-clients is easy to estimate and might take weeks or months to complete that in July.
